title: Jesus' Authority and Ministry
shortSummary: Mark Chapter 2 highlights Jesus' authority to forgive sins, His power to heal, and His call to follow Him. The chapter also addresses controversies regarding His association with sinners, the practice of fasting, and Sabbath observance, emphasizing the new covenant He brings. This chapter reveals Jesus as the Son of Man with divine authority and compassion.
timeline: c. AD 27-29 - Early Galilean Ministry of Jesus

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of Man who teaches, heals, forgives sins, and calls disciples, demonstrating His divine authority.

keyCharacters.name: Levi (Matthew)
keyCharacters.description: A tax collector called by Jesus to follow Him, illustrating Jesus’ call to sinners.

keyCharacters.name: Scribes
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who question Jesus’ authority and accuse Him of blasphemy for forgiving sins.

keyCharacters.name: Pharisees
keyCharacters.description: Jewish religious leaders who challenge Jesus on His association with sinners and His disciples’ behavior.

definitions.definition: A condition involving paralysis or weakness, often used in the Bible to describe those unable to walk.
Tax collectors who were often despised by Jews for collaborating with Roman authorities and perceived as sinners.
The bread placed on a table in the temple, reserved for priests, symbolizing God's provision.
Speaking irreverently about God or claiming divine attributes, considered a grave sin in Jewish law.
A Messianic title Jesus uses for Himself, emphasizing both His humanity and divine authority.

outline.heading: Jesus Heals the Paralytic and Forgives Sins
outline.description: Jesus returns to Capernaum where a large crowd gathers. Four men bring a paralytic to Jesus, who forgives his sins and heals him, demonstrating His authority to forgive sins on earth, provoking the scribes’ accusations of blasphemy.

outline.heading: Jesus Calls Levi and Eats with Sinners
outline.description: Jesus calls Levi, a tax collector, to follow Him. He dines with many sinners and publicans, illustrating His mission to call sinners to repentance, which draws criticism from the Pharisees.

outline.heading: Questions About Fasting
outline.description: Jesus explains why His disciples do not fast while He, the bridegroom, is present, using parables about new cloth and new wine to show the incompatibility of the new covenant with old religious practices.

outline.heading: Jesus and the Sabbath Controversy
outline.description: Jesus defends His disciples’ actions on the Sabbath by referencing David’s example and teaching that the Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath, declaring Himself Lord of the Sabbath.

application: Trust in Jesus’ authority to forgive sins and bring spiritual healing in your life.
Follow Jesus’ example of compassion by reaching out to those considered outcasts or sinners.
Understand that religious practices must not hinder the new life and freedom found in Christ.
Honor the Sabbath by focusing on its purpose to serve and restore, recognizing Jesus as Lord over it.

keyVerses.text: When Jesus saw their faith, he said unto the sick of the palsy, Son, thy sins be forgiven thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals Jesus’ authority to forgive sins, a divine prerogative that confirms His identity as the Son of God.

keyVerses.text: When Jesus heard it, he saith unto them, They that are whole have no need of the physician, but they that are sick: I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Jesus’ mission to call sinners to repentance, emphasizing His grace and mercy.

keyVerses.text: And he said unto them, The sabbath was made for man, and not man for the sabbath:
keyVerses.significance: Jesus teaches the true purpose of the Sabbath, prioritizing human need over legalistic observance.

keyVerses.text: Therefore the Son of man is Lord also of the sabbath.
keyVerses.significance: This declaration affirms Jesus’ divine authority over religious law and practice.
